content.description:
ESTIMATED INFANT MORTALITY RATES IN WESTERN EUROPE AS A PERCENTAGE OF LIVE BIRTHS

Pre-1750
 1740–1790
 1780–1820

England
 18.7
 16.1
 12.2

France
 25.2
 21.3
 19.5

Spain
 28.1
 27.3
 22.0

Switzerland
 28.3

 25.5

Sweden
 NA
 22.5
 18.7

Source: Adapted from Michael Flinn, The European Demographic System, 1500–1820, Johns Hopkins University Press, 1981, table 6.9, p. 92.

The data in the table were derived from an analysis of parish church records in the various countries.
content.question: All of the following statements are factually accurate. Which one would most limit the data’s usefulness for drawing conclusions about general demographic trends in western Europe in the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries?

choices.label: The parishes from which the data were derived were predominantly rural.
Parish priests and ministers recorded birth and death dates as part of their duty to provide baptism and burial services to their parishioners.
The periods covered by the data all saw major conflicts that affected large parts of western Europe.
National governments did not regularly collect census information about birth and death rates in the period covered by the data table.

content.answer: The parishes from which the data were derived were predominantly rural.

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Explain how claims or evidence support, modify, or refute a source's argument.
